overview: This subject cultivates the student’s fluency with the practical and theoretical elements of contemporary music making.

Concepts and structures relating to rhythm, harmony, contemporary scoring practices and real time ensemble balancing are explored through an experiential pedagogy where students learn the techniques of leading a contemporary music ensemble in original creative composition.
Students attend Languages of Music (an interactive workshop/lecture) which is supported by practical small group tutorials for each of the three areas of: harmonic, rhythmic and practical devices.
The assessment combines written examination and practical application.
intended learning outcomes: apply key elements of contemporary repertoire to individual performance practice with a view to innovation and sustainable artistic practice;
produce creative work in response to history and styles of improvised music investigated in Contextual Studies 3;
transcribe, identify and perform selected melodies, rhythms and harmonic structures;
identify and perform selected rhythmic and polyrhythmic patterns;
perform melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic tasks illustrating aural comprehension;
utilise theoretical conventions of music and apply these to jazz and improvisation practices.

assessments.description: Languages of Music Written Exam. 800 words (equivalent)
Three 4-minute in-class practical tests: Harmonic Devices;  Rhythmic Devices; Practical Devices.. 30 hours (of work required)
Three 4-minute practical exams: Harmonic Devices; Rhythmic Devices; Practical Devices.. 30 hours (of work required)
Hurdle requirement:. Students must attend a minimum of 80% of all lectures, tutorials, and practical classes.

Semester 2.Contact hours: 51 hours, comprising one 2‐hour Languages of Music lecture/workshop, and three 45‐minute practical tutorials per week
